problem: Question: Kyoto Joe, Inc., sells earnings forecasts for Japanese securities. Its credit terms are 2/10, net 30. Kyoto Joe sells 1,500 forecasts every month at a price of $1,900 each.What is the average balance sheet amount in accounts receivable? (Unit: dollar)
reasoning: From S4 and S4_calc, monthly sales are 1,500 forecasts × $1,900 = $2,850,000 per month. Assuming a 30-day month (S5, S5_calc), average daily sales are $2,850,000 ÷ 30 = $95,000 per day. With an assumed 30-day collection period (S2), average accounts receivable equals daily sales × collection period = $95,000 × 30 = $2,850,000 (S6, S6_calc). Rounded to the nearest dollar (S7, S7_calc), the result is 2,850,000 dollars.

state.problem: Question: Kyoto Joe, Inc., sells earnings forecasts for Japanese securities. Its credit terms are 2/10, net 30. Kyoto Joe sells 1,500 forecasts every month at a price of $1,900 each.What is the average balance sheet amount in accounts receivable? (Unit: dollar)
state.goal: Compute the average accounts receivable balance (in dollars, as a numeric value with appropriate rounding) for Kyoto Joe, Inc., given its sales volume, price, and credit terms.
givens: Product: earnings forecasts for Japanese securities
Number of forecasts sold each month: 1,500
unknowns: Average accounts receivable balance (in dollars) under the given credit terms and sales pattern
invariants: Final answer must be in monetary units (dollars).
Use the monthly sales rate as a steady-state assumption (uniform sales throughout the month) unless clarified otherwise.
Any numerical computation step MUST use Python tool for calculations. No mental math is allowed.
Intermediate units (e.g., forecasts/month, dollars/forecast, dollars/day) must be tracked and consistent.
The logical relationship between daily sales, days receivable (collection period), and average A/R must be maintained.

plan.title: Extract and restate problem data
plan.description: Identify and restate all given numerical values and conditions from the problem: monthly units sold, price per unit, credit terms, and the requested quantity (average accounts receivable balance). Check that all relevant data for a basic A/R computation is present.
plan.expected_output: A clear list of all numerical givens with units (1,500 forecasts/month, $1,900/forecast, terms 2/10 net 30) and a restatement of the target: average A/R in dollars.
plan.result:
Given data:
- Monthly sales volume: 1,500 forecasts per month
- Price per forecast: $1,900 per forecast
- Credit terms: 2/10, net 30 (2% discount if paid within 10 days; otherwise full amount due in 30 days)
\nTarget: Determine the average accounts receivable balance (in dollars) under these terms, assuming steady, uniform monthly sales.

plan.title: Clarify assumptions about collection period
plan.description: Interpret the credit terms '2/10, net 30' for the purpose of computing average accounts receivable, and choose a working assumption for the average collection period (e.g., assume all customers pay at 30 days unless additional information is given). Document this assumption explicitly.
plan.expected_output: A clearly stated assumption for the average collection period in days (e.g., 30 days) and justification based on typical textbook interpretation, noting that actual mix of discount vs. non-discount customers is unspecified.
plan.result: Assume the average collection period is 30 days, i.e., customers effectively pay on the net-30 due date.

plan.title: Check units and target output format
plan.description: Confirm the units of all inputs (forecasts/month, dollars/forecast, days for collection) and ensure that the formula to be used for average accounts receivable will produce a result in dollars. Confirm that the final requested format is a single numeric dollar amount (e.g., an integer or dollar value with two decimals).
plan.expected_output: A short statement confirming consistent units (time in days, sales per month converted as needed, money in dollars) and that the final output will be one numeric dollar amount representing average A/R.
plan.result: Inputs are in consistent units: sales volume is 1,500 forecasts per month (forecasts/month), price is $1,900 per forecast (dollars/forecast), and the collection period is measured in days (days). Monthly sales will be converted to daily dollar sales (dollars/day), and average accounts receivable will be computed as (dollars/day) × (days), yielding a result in dollars. The final output will be a single numeric dollar amount representing the average accounts receivable balance.

plan.title: Sanity and consistency check
plan.description: Check whether the average accounts receivable amount is reasonable relative to monthly sales (e.g., if the collection period is about one month, the A/R should be roughly on the order of one month’s sales). plan.result: The computed average accounts receivable of 2,850,000 dollars is reasonable and consistent: it matches exactly one month of sales given a 30-day collection period, with all units (dollars, days, per month) used consistently.

state.final_reasoning: From S4 and S4_calc, monthly sales are 1,500 forecasts × $1,900 = $2,850,000 per month. Assuming a 30-day month (S5, S5_calc), average daily sales are $2,850,000 ÷ 30 = $95,000 per day. With an assumed 30-day collection period (S2), average accounts receivable equals daily sales × collection period = $95,000 × 30 = $2,850,000 (S6, S6_calc). Rounded to the nearest dollar (S7, S7_calc), the result is 2,850,000 dollars.
